author: Primrose Riordan
title: The National Gallery of Australia to feature Tom Roberts
text:
National Gallery of Australia Director Dr. Gerard Vaughan, and Tom Roberts Curator Dr Anna Gray. Jamila Toderas Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Primrose Riordan The National Gallery of Australia is to be reorganised to give new prominence to Australian artists in a dramatic makeover coinciding with the lead-up to the gallery's new summer "blockbuster," starring the works of 19th-century Antipodean painter Tom Roberts.
Recently-appointed director Gerard Vaughan said the move was not about crowd numbers but about the gallery doing its job. He said sometimes the NGA "needs to give blockbuster status to our own heroes".
Arts Minister George Brandis made the announcement alongside Dr Vaughan, saying Robert's works were a study of "the early years of Australian history".
"The works of Tom Roberts are some of Australia's best known, best loved. They capture so much of the early Australian colonial spirit and so many have become iconic," Mr Brandis said.
Tom Roberts' painting Shearing the Rams, 1890. The Tom Roberts exhibition will feature over 130 works. Roughly half are portraits and half landscapes, and include paintings, pastels, drawings, printing and sculpture.
Mr Vaughan conceded it may not generate the same excitement or numbers as last summer's James Turrell exhibition, but the gallery had to do its job by celebrating Australian culture.
"We must, as the National Gallery of Australia based in Canberra, we must celebrate in a blockbuster way our own visual culture.
"An Australian blockbuster is not going to sell the number of tickets as post-impressionism from the Mus√©e d'Orsay. We know that, we do our market research. But it is part of our job and it is not all about numbers," he said.
 Move away from chronology The re-hang will see the Australian collection brought onto level one of the building and the international collection, including Jackson Pollock's Blue Poles , moved upstairs.
Mr Vaughan said the gallery wanted to move away from the chronological hang as the style was "looking a little old-fashioned".
"We wanted to come up with a new way of turning the collections over and making more things available so the idea of having these themes [is] something that makes sense," he said.
The Arts minister and Mr Vaughan are also keen to get the yet-to-be-produced Tom Roberts catalogue into schools. The exhibition was "extremely important for school students," said Mr Vaughan.
"[It] is sure to become the authoritative source on Tom Roberts for a generation. We are hoping to find a way to ensure that every school in Australia will have a copy in their library."
